author: By Declan Walsh
title: Kenyan President’s State Visit: An Antidote to U.S. Troubles in Africa?
description: The White House is hosting President William Ruto of Kenya for a state dinner this week, an embrace that both countries urgently need.
content: As other African nations move away from the United States, disillusioned with democracy or lured by rival powers, President William Ruto of Kenya arrives in Washington on Wednesday for a three-day state visit intended to showcase a stalwart American ally on the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. Inflation Falls to 2.3%, Lowest in 3 Years
description: The decline, which was less than economists expected, is nearing the Bank of England’s 2 percent target.
content: Britain’s inflation rate slowed last month to its lowest level in about three years, further cementing the case for the Bank of England to cut interest rates later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Dead Monkeys Are Falling From Trees Amid Brutal Heat in Mexico
description: The deaths of dozens of howler monkeys may be the latest sign of the danger extreme temperatures pose to wildlife around the world.
content: Gilberto Pozo, a biologist, was monitoring a small forest in the town of Cunduacán, in southern Mexico, in early May when two mantled howler monkeys fell from a tree in front of him with a thud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.6 Million Homes in North Carolina, Florida and Rhode Island
description: An 1880 Queen Anne Revival home in Durham, a two-bedroom condominium in Palm Beach and a modern farmhouse with a detached studio in Barrington.
content: This house, built around 1880 by James Manning, a judge, is known locally as the Bull Durham House, because it appeared in the 1988 movie. The sellers updated it, but took care to maintain original details, including pocket doors, plaster ceiling medallions and ornate mantels. It is about a 20-minute walk from the Carolina Theatre, the Durham Performing Arts Center and the Durham Bulls Athletic Park, as well as a number of breweries, a food hall and a farmers’ market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: She Just Earned Her Doctorate at 17. Now, She’ll Go to the Prom.
description: Dorothy Jean Tillman II of Chicago made history as the youngest person to earn a doctoral degree in integrated behavioral health at Arizona State University.
content: When Dorothy Jean Tillman II successfully defended her dissertation in November 2023 to earn her doctoral degree from Arizona State University, she couldn’t wait to share the news with her best friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,068
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W.J. Hennigan
title: The Victims of U.S. Nuclear Testing Deserve More Than This
description: Speaker Mike Johnson should let the House vote on extending and expanding RECA, and our lawmakers should vote yes.
content: The men and women came to Capitol Hill last week bearing surgical scars, long medical histories and fading photographs of loved ones long dead. They came from across the country to walk the halls of Congress and show lawmakers the human cost of the U.S. nuclear weapons program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hetty Lui McKinnon and Alice Callahan
title: How to Become a Vegetarian (or Simply Eat More Plants)
description: Your health and cooking questions, answered.
content: Longtime vegetarians already know: To be a vegetarian is to eat really well. But if you’re looking to make the switch to vegetarianism or just a more plant-forward diet, you may have questions, even concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Mayor Adams Fills a Key Commission With Allies and Donors
description: Mayor Eric Adams named 13 people to a prominent city commission that could remake city government. Most are loyalists or have ties to his inner circle.
content: Mayor Eric Adams has long valued loyalty, keeping his allies close as he rose through New York City’s political ranks to become mayor, and rewarding them with top administration jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Homeowners Feel Pinch as Insurers Bleed Losses
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 22, 2024
content: “I believe we’re marching toward an uninsurable future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 347, May 23, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: On Campus, a New Social Litmus Test: Zionist or Not?
description: Some Jewish students say they’ve been dropped by old roommates and sorority sisters and ostracized from campus clubs and teams because of their views — which are sometimes assumed.
content: Last fall, a Barnard College sophomore named Sophie Fisher reached out to her freshman year roommate to catch up over coffee. Her old friend’s response was tepid, and Ms. Fisher wondered why. The two had been close enough that the roommate had come to the bar mitzvah of Ms. Fisher’s brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats See Wins in Losing Votes
description: The party is pursuing a “sword and shield” political strategy as Senator Chuck Schumer pushes showdown votes on border security and abortion rights ahead of this year’s elections.
content: In losing big votes, Senator Chuck Schumer, the New York Democrat and majority leader, believes his party stands to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe
title: Fraud Trial Begins for Chinese Billionaire Who Allied Himself With America’s Right
description: Charged with defrauding thousands of investors in the U.S. and overseas of more than $1 billion, Guo Wengui could face decades in prison.
content: Four years ago, Guo Wengui, a prominent Chinese property developer, announced the imminent end of Communist rule and the formation of the New Federal State of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Exit the Modest Merchant Prince
description: Bruce Nordstrom was both the force behind his family’s multibillion-dollar retail dynasty and a stealth godfather to the fashion trade.
content: “Nice” tends to be dirty word in business. The cliché holding that nice guys finish last has seldom seemed more true than in the landscape of contemporary retailing, where business is dominated by corporate consolidation, monopolistic practices and shareholder returns as the ultimate value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: What We Know About the Ambani Wedding
description: Anant Ambani and Radhika Merchant’s pre-wedding in March caused a stir when photos and videos of their lavish celebration circulated on social media. Here’s what we know about their July nuptials.
content: Even in a country known for grandiose weddings, Anant Ambani, the son of India’s richest man, and Radhika Merchant’s three-day pre-wedding celebration earlier this year in India stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Emma Bubola and Michael Levenson
title: Spain, Norway and Ireland Recognize Palestinian State, Further Isolating Israel
description: The moves, while largely symbolic, were welcomed by Palestinians and denounced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who called them “a prize for terrorism.”
content: Spain, Norway and Ireland said on Wednesday that they would recognize an independent Palestinian state, delivering a diplomatic blow to Israel that showed the country’s growing isolation on the world stage more than seven months into its devastating military offensive in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Hogla Enecia Pérez
title: Dominican President Abinader Wins Re-election in a Landslide
description: In election results made official Tuesday night, President Luis Abinader easily won his re-election bid, helped by restrictions on Haitian migrants, a vibrant economy and an anti-corruption drive.
content: President Luis Abinader of the Dominican Republic won his re-election bid in a landslide, bolstered by sweeping restrictions on Haitian migrants and a strong economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Gender Pay Gap Is a Culture Problem
description: Policy alone won’t get women what they deserve.
content: American women made significant progress toward closing the gender pay gap in the second half of the 20th century, but that gap has barely budged over the past two decades. In 2022, according to Pew Research, “American women typically earned 82 cents for every dollar earned by men. That was about the same as in 2002, when they earned 80 cents to the dollar.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York Begins a New Wave of Evictions From Migrant Shelters
description: The evictions are part of an aggressive strategy to force some adult migrants out of city shelters after 30 or 60 days.
content: New York City began a new push to evict migrants from its shelter system on Wednesday as the city enters a more aggressive phase in its effort to ease the strain that the migrant crisis has placed on the city’s budget and shelters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Cowles
title: The Essential Don DeLillo
description: His fascination with terrorism, cults and mass culture’s weirder turns has given his work a prophetic air. Here’s where to start.
content: For years when I was younger, and still dreamed that I might be a novelist instead of an editor or a critic, I kept a quote from Don DeLillo’s 1993 Paris Review interview pinned to the bulletin board above my desk as a sort of talisman or goad prompting me to write: “Do you think it made a difference in your career,” Adam Begley asked him, “that you started writing novels late, when you were approaching 30?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Kennedy Adviser Leaves Campaign, Citing ‘Hateful and Divisive Atmosphere’ in Politics
description: Angela Stanton King, a former Trump supporter who joined the campaign in December, was a high-profile figure in Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s circle.
content: A key adviser to Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is stepping away from his presidential campaign, citing an “increasingly hateful and divisive atmosphere” in politics that “no longer aligns with my values.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sunak Announces U.K. Elections for July 4, Months Earlier Than Expected
description: The opposition Labour Party has been ahead in most polls by double digits in recent months.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain on Wednesday called a snap general election for July 4, throwing the fate of his embattled Conservative Party to a restless British public that appears eager for change after 14 years of Conservative government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Alicia Keys, Usher and Patti Smith Honor the Legacy of Gordon Parks
description: This year’s gala for the Gordon Parks Foundation raised close to $2.3 million, and drew out Spike Lee, Colin Kaepernick and Ben Stiller.
content: For a moment, the annual Gordon Parks Foundation gala felt like a church service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaks to The Times
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the U.S. and Europe to do more to defend Ukraine, in a wide-ranging interview with The Times. He proposed that NATO planes shoot down Russian missiles in Ukrainian airspace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Kebede-Twumasi and Matt Stevens
title: Judge Blocks Attempt to Sell Graceland, at Least for Now
description: Elvis’s granddaughter, the actress Riley Keough, had filed a lawsuit seeking to stop what her lawyers said was a fraudulent auction of her family home.
content: Graceland will not be sold at auction, at least for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Georgia Supreme Court Justice Fends Off Challenger Who Made Abortion Rights a Focus
description: Justice Andrew Pinson, who was appointed by the state’s Republican governor, faced an opponent who argued that the Georgia Constitution guaranteed the right to an abortion.
content: The incumbent in the lone competitive race for a seat on the Georgia Supreme Court won re-election on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, fending off a challenge from a former Democratic congressman who had built his campaign in the nonpartisan contest on protecting abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Doug Emhoff Calls Trump a ‘Known Antisemite’ as Biden Team Steps Up Attacks
description: The remarks by Mr. Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, represented an escalation of the Biden campaign’s attacks on Donald Trump over his language about Jews.
content: Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, called former President Donald J. Trump “a known antisemite” in a video released on Tuesday, a notable escalation of attacks by President Biden’s campaign against Mr. Trump over his language about Jews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Haley Says She Will Vote for Trump, in Her First Appearance Since Dropping Out
description: Nikki Haley had sharp words for President Biden and some Republicans.
content: In her first public appearance since she dropped her Republican presidential bid in March, Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador, on Wednesday said she would vote for former President Donald J. Trump, stopping short of an official endorsement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Inside the White House, a Debate Over Letting Ukraine Shoot U.S. Weapons Into Russia
description: After a sobering trip to Kyiv, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken is urging the president to lift restrictions on how Ukraine can use American arms.
content: Since the first American shipments of sophisticated weapons to Ukraine, President Biden has never wavered on one prohibition: President Volodymyr Zelensky had to agree to never fire them into Russian territory, insisting that would violate Mr. Biden’s mandate to “avoid World War III.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: Businesses in D.C. Blame the Government for the District’s Empty Offices
description: Workers in Washington have returned to the office slowly, with a pervasive and pronounced effect on the local economy.
content: Kostas Fostieris grew wistful as he remembered the workday crowds that once flocked to Greek Deli & Catering, a small restaurant a few blocks from the White House that he has operated for 35 years. At lunch, the line would stretch down the block, Mr. Fostieris said. But then the coronavirus pandemic swept the nation, and the lunch crowds vanished. They have yet to return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Laments That Donald Trump Didn’t Testify at His Trial
description: Jimmy Fallon said Trump wanted to take the stand in his criminal case on Tuesday, “but then he saw it was three steps without a handrail.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: ‘Dropping Very Dramatically’: What Deadly Turbulence Did to a Flight
description: Singapore Airlines flight SQ321 was a rare instance of turbulence resulting in a death.
content: The seatbelt sign came on moments after the plane started shaking, but, for some, it was too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Western Europe Is Starting to Send a Vital Warning to Israel
description: Netanyahu’s government can’t ignore what the world is saying about the need for a Palestinian state.
content: The decision by Spain, Norway and Ireland on Wednesday to recognize an independent Palestinian state marks the latest brick in the wall of rejection being built around Israel’s current far-right government, which is asking the world to let it destroy Hamas in Gaza while refusing to work on a new future with non-Hamas Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck and Emily Cochrane
title: Abortion Pills May Become Controlled Substances in Louisiana
description: A bill that is expected to pass would impose prison time and thousands of dollars in fines on people possessing the pills without a prescription.
content: Louisiana could become the first state to classify abortion pills as dangerous controlled substances, making possession of the pills without a prescription a crime subject to jail time and fines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: New Video Shows Hamas Fighters Taking Israeli Soldiers Hostage
description: The Israeli military showed family members of the hostages the video a few weeks ago and gave them a copy on Tuesday, which they shared.
content: The families of several Israeli female soldiers taken hostage during the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7 have released video of their abduction in an attempt to pressure the Israeli government to revive stalled cease-fire talks that could pave the way for the captives’ release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan and Christina Caron
title: Is Fluoridated Drinking Water Safe for Pregnant Women?
description: New research suggests a link between prenatal fluoride levels and behavioral issues in children. Experts are divided on the study’s significance.
content: A small study published Monday suggested that higher levels of fluoride consumed during the third trimester of pregnancy were associated with a greater risk of behavioral problems in the mothers’ children at 3 years old. The authors of the study, which was funded in part by the National Institutes of Health and the Environmental Protection Agency and published in the journal JAMA Network Open, believe it is the first to examine links between prenatal fluoride exposure and child development among families living in the United States, where fluoride is often added to community water supplies to prevent dental cavities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: At Which Museum or Venue Would You Like to Spend the Night?
description: A planetarium? A Broadway theater? A baseball stadium? A famous library? Where would you most love to have a sleepover?
content: Imagine having free rein at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, with its famous Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton and life-size model of a blue whale. Or getting a chance to see the Terra Cotta Army in Xi’an, China, without the crowds. Or exploring the seminal Sydney Opera House in Australia after dark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsey Tramuta
title: Where Royals Once Hunted in France, a Green Forest Welcomes Everyone
description: With its boulders, trails and proximity to Paris, the 50,000-acre Forest of Fontainebleau draws millions of hikers, rock-climbers, trail runners and forest bathers each year. Some worry that its popularity is taking a toll.
content: In popular imagination, France’s Fontainebleau is inextricably linked to its grand Château. But when I visit, I typically skip it entirely. Yes, the 1,500-room Château de Fontainebleau that was inhabited by French kings and emperors for eight centuries may seem the most arresting attraction in this region 37 miles south of Paris. Instead, it’s the surrounding forest that entices me to return again and again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Frank Shrontz, 92, Dies; Led Boeing in the Last of Its Golden Years
description: Known for his leadership and his commitment to company culture, he left as chief executive in 1996, opening the door to a corporate makeover.
content: Frank Shrontz, a widely admired executive who led Boeing in the 1980s and ’90s, a decade of spectacular growth in both its bottom line and its prestige as one of the world’s premier aerospace companies — a period very different from its current crisis of public confidence — died on May 3 at an assisted living home in Seattle. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Stephanie Saul
title: Anyone Want to Be a College President? There Are (Many) Openings
description: The job is not what it used to be. There are openings at U.C.L.A., Yale, Harvard, Cornell, Penn … and many, many others.
content: To glimpse the tumultuous transitions in American college leadership these days, look no further than the witnesses set to testify at a congressional hearing on Thursday, the fourth in a fiery series on campus antisemitism that has helped topple two university presidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dinaw Mengestu
title: How Should the Stories of Migrants Be Told?
description: “The Silence of the Choir,” a novel by Mohamed Mbougar Sarr, follows 72 African refugees who have arrived in a Sicilian village.
content: At some point in recent history, the merits of reading literary fiction became inextricably entwined with the genre’s potential to instill empathy, particularly for characters whose lives are radically different from our own. In this context, literature has tangible (and perhaps commercial) value in no small part because of our hope that what is true on the page might be true in reality. If we encounter unknown, unfamiliar or even unlikable characters in a novel, and still find room in our hearts to care for them, then perhaps we will be more likely to do so when such figures wash up on our own shores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: A Dreamy Bean Dip in Under 30 Minutes
description: Topped with deeply browned onions, this snack is as simple or complex as you make it.
content: It was the word “frazzled,” I think, that set me off. It was all meant to be very simple. I was to write a recipe for a superquick dip, using pantry ingredients, ready in under 30 minutes. Delicious. Easy. No need to overthink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Are Ayo Edebiri and Jeremy Allen White Dating?
description: Whether or not the rumors are true, the co-stars’ apparent bond continues to fascinate fans and serves as a reminder that some people are still rooting for love.
content: When Vanity Fair asked Jeremy Allen White to share a statement about Ayo Edebiri, his co-star on the series “The Bear,” for its profile on the actress, it was reported that the actor made time “within a day” of being asked, a rare occurrence for a busy celebrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Despite Setback, Neuralink’s First Brain-Implant Patient Stays Upbeat
description: Elon Musk’s first human experiment with a computerized brain device developed significant flaws, but the subject, who is paralyzed, has few regrets.
content: Just four months ago, Noland Arbaugh had a circle of bone removed from his skull and hair-thin sensor tentacles slipped into his brain. A computer about the size of a small stack of quarters was placed on top and the hole was sealed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Federal Spending Rescued Mass Transit During Covid. What Happens Now?
description: The government provided $69.5 billion in relief funds to help keep transit on track during Covid-19. But many rail and bus systems are now facing layoffs and cutbacks.
content: As commuter buses and trains ran nearly empty at the height of the Covid-19 pandemic, the federal government stepped in with $69.5 billion in relief funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman, Ernesto Londoño and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: 3 More College Leaders to Face Congress Over Antisemitism Claims
description: The heads of Rutgers, Northwestern and U.C.L.A. will be the first university leaders to testify since a wave of protest encampments roiled college campuses.
content: For the fourth time in six months, the Republican-led House Committee on Education and the Workforce is summoning school leaders to Washington to be questioned about accusations of antisemitism at their institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Recognizing a Palestinian State, Ireland Nods to its Own History
description: Simon Harris, Ireland’s prime minister, invoked his nation’s struggle for independence from Britain and its decades of violent sectarian conflict.
content: When the Irish government on Wednesday announced formal recognition of an independent Palestinian state, it drew on its own struggle for statehood and the violence that surrounded it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: The War Is Shifting Europe’s Politics Away From Israel
description: The recognition of Palestinian statehood by Spain, Ireland and Norway highlights the changing center of gravity, but there also are staunchly pro-Israel nations in Europe.
content: In Europe, long a vital source of support for Israel, the political center of gravity is moving away from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: A Trump Rally in the Bronx? Some Residents Ask Why.
description: Donald J. Trump’s first rally in New York in eight years will be in the Bronx. Borough residents had mixed reactions.
content: After weeks of being the headline-grabbing defendant in a criminal trial in Manhattan, Donald J. Trump will head to Crotona Park in the Bronx for a rally on Thursday where he no doubt hopes to take a more favorable star turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristina Kuzmič
title: My Son Was in a Psychiatric Hospital. Why Was I Celebrating?
description: In the midst of a family crisis, a writer contemplates whether heartache and joy can coexist.
content: My 40th birthday celebration had been in the works for months. The plan was as follows: On Friday, my husband was throwing a party for me in the private room of a hillside restaurant with gorgeous views of Los Angeles. Our closest friends and family would be there. Philip had hired a D.J., rented a photo booth, ordered a three-tiered chocolate cake and picked out an eclectic menu of my favorite dishes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 22, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 22, 2024.
content: A Critic’s Notebook article on Saturday about the symbolism of a cartoon character of a Palestinian boy, known as Handala, included a misstatement from Margaret Olin, a religious studies scholar at the Yale Divinity School. It is not the case that her son’s in-laws have a bumper sticker with the Handala image on their car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Transferred From Brooklyn Jail
description: The FTX founder’s final destination wasn’t clear, but Mr. Bankman-Fried has told people close to him that he expected to be moved to a facility in Mendota, Calif.
content: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy, was transferred out of a Brooklyn detention center on Wednesday morning, his spokesman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: To See the Past and Predict the Future, Try ‘Reading’ a Landscape
description: How well do you know your own backyard? Noah Charney thinks you should take another look.
content: When Noah Charney and his wife were house-shopping near Philadelphia, one real estate agent after another claimed to have the ideal home for them, and couldn’t wait to offer a virtual tour of its features: the renovated kitchen, the ample closet space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Northeast Corridor Train Service Resumes Following Overnight Meltdown
description: Fallen electrical wires in New Jersey brought Amtrak and New Jersey Transit service to a halt on the Northeast Corridor Wednesday night, and transit agencies warned of delays into Thursday.
content: Train service along the Northeast Corridor south of New York City ground to a halt Wednesday evening because of fallen overhead power cables in Kearny, N.J., stranding commuters and travelers and leading to potential delays into the Thursday morning commute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Vials of Blood Sent to R.N.C. Headquarters Prompt Lockdown
description: Hazardous materials teams responded to the Republican National Committee headquarters in Washington after a suspicious package was found.
content: A suspicious package with two vials of blood prompted a lockdown at the Republican National Committee headquarters in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Ali MacGraw on Her Natural, Beautiful Life
description: With “Love Story,” she shot to Hollywood stardom at 30. It wasn’t until later that the actress, now 85, found fulfillment in New Mexico.
content: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Ali MacGraw explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor, Aric Toler and Julie Tate
title: Another Provocative Flag Was Flown at Another Alito Home
description: The justice’s beach house displayed an “Appeal to Heaven” flag, a symbol carried on Jan. 6 and associated with a push for a more Christian-minded government.
content: Last summer, two years after an upside-down American flag was flown outside the Virginia home of Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., another provocative symbol was displayed at his vacation house in New Jersey, according to interviews and photographs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Billie Eilish Is Done Hiding
description: A conversation about the pop singer’s new album, “Hit Me Hard and Soft.”
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Staffing Crisis at Federal Prisons Highlighted in Oregon
description: Delays for medical care were severe enough to force one inmate at the prison to fake a suicide attempt to obtain treatment for a serious infection.
content: An inmate at a federal prison in Oregon faked a suicide attempt to obtain medical treatment for a serious infection because health care staffing levels were so low that patients were forced to wait days, or even weeks, for basic care, an independent watchdog found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: OpenAI Strikes a Deal to License News Corp Content
description: The deal gives OpenAI’s chatbots access to new and archived material from The Wall Street Journal, The New York Post, MarketWatch and Barron’s, among others.
content: News Corp, the Murdoch-owned empire of publications like The Wall Street Journal and The New York Post, announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to a deal with OpenAI to share its content to train and service artificial intelligence chatbots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: ‘The Hunt for Gollum’ Was Just Announced. It Was on YouTube in 2009.
description: When Warner Bros. greenlit a new “Lord of the Rings” movie and a 15-year-old fan film with the same title disappeared, its devotees sprang into action.
content: In 2009, Chris Bouchard, a recent film school graduate, uploaded his 39-minute “Lord of the Rings” fan film, “The Hunt for Gollum,” to YouTube. At the time, the platform was still, in his words, full of “five-minute videos of people’s cats.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Chicago Is Tired of Waiting for Trains, and Thinks It Knows Who’s to Blame
description: The Chicago City Council is seeking the public transit chief’s ouster as the system wrestles with financial woes, sluggish service and crime complaints since the pandemic.
content: Until recently, Dorval R. Carter Jr. was another relatively unknown bureaucrat, a man who had quietly worked under three mayors as the president of the Chicago Transit Authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Leily Nikounazar
title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Leads Funeral Prayers for President
description: State news media in Iran reported that the political leader of Hamas was in the capital for the funeral. Many foreign dignitaries attended.
content: Crowds packed the streets of Tehran and Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, performed funeral prayers on Wednesday for the country’s president, with senior officials from the Iranian-backed militant groups Hamas and Hezbollah joining the commemorations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: The Algebra Problem: How Middle School Math Became a National Flashpoint
description: Top students can benefit greatly by being offered the subject early. But many districts offer few Black and Latino eighth graders a chance to study it.
content: From suburbs in the Northeast to major cities on the West Coast, a surprising subject is prompting ballot measures, lawsuits and bitter fights among parents: algebra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Voters Oust Progressive Prosecutor in Portland
description: Mike Schmidt lost to Nathan Vasquez, a deputy district attorney in Multnomah County, Ore., who blamed his boss for the area’s recent problems with drugs and crime.
content: Mike Schmidt, the progressive prosecutor in Portland, Ore., who has held office during a tumultuous period of street protests, drug overdoses and violent crime, lost his seat to a co-worker who has called for more aggressive prosecution of criminals, The Associated Press said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Andrew E. Kramer, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Zelensky Urges Allies to Do More, and Trump’s Defense Rests
description: Plus, America’s monster in Afghanistan.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Petterson and Christine Hauser
title: 5 Dead as Iowa Reels From Tornado
description: Severe weather destroyed much of Greenfield, where officials were continuing search and rescue work. At least 35 people were injured.
content: Southwestern Iowa was reeling Wednesday after a destructive wave of storms, including a tornado, swept across the state the day before, leaving five people dead and at least 35 injured, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Koba Ryckewaert
title: Belgium’s 2024 Election: What to Know
description: Belgium, a small yet politically significant country, will hold federal, regional, and E.U. elections on June 9, for control of its complex, layered governance structure.
content: For a relatively small country of 11.5 million in northern Europe, Belgium punches above its weight in political relevance and drama, all of which is set to play out on June 9 when Belgians head to the polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 347
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Melissa Clark’s Go-To Pizza Recipe for Busy Nights
description: This olive oil-enriched recipe is the fastest version you can make from scratch — and it’s one of the best.
content: For years, as soon as the craving for homemade pizza struck me, it was very easy to gratify … four days later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump Prosecutor Wins, McCarthy’s Successor Is Set and Other Election Takeaways
description: In Georgia, the prosecutor and judge in Donald Trump’s criminal case won their races easily, and a Trump-backed California legislator will finish former Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s term.
content: Vince Fong, a state lawmaker in California and onetime aide to former Speaker Kevin McCarthy, won a special election on Tuesday to fill his seat — representing the most conservative district in the deep-blue state. Mr. Fong succeeds Mr. McCarthy nearly five months after he resigned from Congress, following his ouster from the speakership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: A Reparations Effort in Palm Springs
description: Black and Latino families whose neighborhood was razed in the 1960s are seeking compensation from the city.
content: Palm Springs used to have a neighborhood called Section 14, where many of the desert resort’s gardeners, janitors, construction workers and housekeepers, most of them Black or Latino, lived with their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: San Francisco’s Hot Tourist Attraction: Driverless Cars
description: Cable cars are still trundling up the city’s hills, but robotaxis from Waymo are shaping up as the city’s latest must-do for visitors.
content: When David De Clercq traveled to San Francisco last year, he had a few musts on his itinerary: Go to Alcatraz. Try new restaurants. And ride in a self-driving car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azam Ahmed
title: Investigating a Monster: What We Found and How We Did It
description: The end of the war in Afghanistan and the fall of its government allowed us to reach previously inaccessible records, places and people, documenting the bloody history of a key American ally.
content: The only thing faster than the American withdrawal from Afghanistan might be how quickly the world moved on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Why Norway’s Recognition of a Palestinian State Carries Significance
description: Norway hosted the clandestine meetings in 1993 that led to the Oslo Accords, the framework for peace that came close to resolving the conflict.
content: Scores of countries have recognized a Palestinian state, but Norway’s announcement on Wednesday that it would do so carried added significance because it hosted the clandestine meetings in 1993 that led to the Oslo Accords, the framework for peace that came close to resolving the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians. It ultimately failed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel Responds to Move to Recognize Palestinian State by Withholding Funds
description: The finance minister’s office signaled that the decision, which could worsen the Palestinians’ dire economic crisis, was a response to Spain, Norway and Ireland recognizing Palestinian statehood.
content: Israel will not transfer much-needed funds to the Palestinian Authority in the wake of the decision by three European countries to recognize a Palestinian state, the country’s finance minister said on Wednesday, as its foreign minister denounced the European moves as giving “a gold medal to Hamas terrorists.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azam Ahmed
title: A Hidden History
description: A Times investigation uncovered a brutal campaign enacted by U.S.-backed forces during the war in Afghanistan.
content: General Abdul Raziq was one of America’s fiercest allies in the fight against the Taliban. He was young and charismatic — a courageous warrior who commanded the loyalty and respect of his men. He helped beat back the Taliban in the crucial battlefield of Kandahar, even as the insurgents advanced across Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Falsely Claims Biden Administration Was ‘Locked & Loaded’ to Kill Him
description: Former President Donald J. Trump misrepresented a standard Justice Department policy to claim the F.B.I. was ready to kill him when searching his home in 2022.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump accused the Biden administration on Tuesday of having been prepared to kill him during a 2022 search for classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, his private club and residence in Palm Beach, Fla., making the false claim that President Biden was “locked & loaded” in a fund-raising email.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Democrats Favor Janelle Bynum in Bid to Flip Oregon Congressional Seat
description: In a race that could help decide control of the U.S. House, Democrats chose State Representative Bynum to compete against Lori Chavez-DeRemer, the Republican incumbent.
content: In one of the most closely watched congressional races in the country, Democrats in Oregon have chosen State Representative Janelle Bynum to challenge the Republican incumbent, Lori Chavez-DeRemer, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Doesn’t My Husband Respect My Opinion About Moving?
description: After 20 years in a house that was never meant to be a “forever home,” a reader thinks it’s time for a move, but her husband refuses to consider her wishes.
content: My husband and I have lived in the same house for 20 years. It’s modest, which allowed me to stay home with our children when they were young. My husband worked hard to pay off the mortgage, and I’m grateful to him. But this was never meant to be our forever home. It’s near a busy street with lots of noise and traffic. I’ve wanted to move to a quieter location for several years, but my husband emphatically refuses. We are both working full time now, and we are bringing in more money. I believe this should be a joint decision, but he doesn’t seem to value my opinion. Am I being unreasonable?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Power Struggle in Vietnam Brings Third President in Less Than 2 Years
description: But it remains unclear whether Gen. To Lam, the new president, can rise to the post of the top leader, the chief of the Vietnamese Communist Party.
content: A powerful security official was named president of Vietnam on Wednesday, the third person in the job in less than 18 months amid jostling ahead of a generational change in leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Curry Roasted Half Chicken and Peppers for One
description: A solo supper that feels positively, well, positive.
content: I have a special dinner for those rare evenings I cook for just myself. When my (cabbage-shy) daughter and (dairy-avoiding) husband aren’t home, I’ll treat myself to a pan of cheesy, spicy cabbage. I sauté shaggy slices of the crucifer in olive oil with garlic or onion, and then finish the dish with chile, either flakes or freshly sliced, and a handful of grated whatever-cheese-is-around. Piled onto buttered sourdough toast or topped with a fried egg, it’s a perfect meal that perfectly feeds one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Justice Alito’s Blame-the-Wife Defense
description: Readers react to several articles about the upside-down flag flown at the justice’s home. Also: The taco court case; G.O.P. denial of benefits; Equinox and equity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Jillian Weinberger
title: Nicholas Kristof: ‘Never Bet Against Democracy in the Long Run’
description: Why, after decades of conflict reporting, the columnist is still hopeful.
content: Nicholas Kristof has spent his career reporting on difficult topics: genocide, war, famine. But decades in the field have not weakened his belief in humanity. In this audio essay, Kristof reflects on his life as a reporter and makes the case for hope. “Yes, there are very real challenges ahead,” he says. And yet, he argues, the United States “has a dynamism and inner strength that will allow America to survive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: An Iowa Town Is Devastated by a Tornado
description: Four people were killed in the area of Greenfield, Iowa, on Tuesday when a tornado ripped through the city, destroying homes and buildings.
content: Powerful storms and at least one tornado ripped through Iowa on Tuesday, killing four people and leaving a path of destroyed homes, mangled cars and downed trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: In ‘Usus,’ Pig Latin Gets Lost in Translation
description: T. Adamson’s new comedy, which opens Clubbed Thumb’s popular Summerworks series at the Wild Project, is about a group of worked-up Franciscan friars.
content: As befits a play set among an order of 14th-century friars, “Usus” occasionally uses Latin words. Sort of. It’s likely that most audience members will understand “vile rat astard-bay” without resorting to a dictionary because pig Latin is still a living language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Is New Haven the Pizza Capital of the U.S.? ‘They’re Outta Their Minds.’
description: A congresswoman from Connecticut declared New Haven the city with the “best pizza in the country” on the House floor. New York City would like a word.
content: Salvatore Carlino knows what it takes to make the perfect New York slice: He grew up in his parents’ pizza shop, Papa Leone, in Brooklyn’s Sheepshead Bay, and now owns his own pizzeria, Lucia, with locations in Brooklyn and Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: New Stamp Design
description: This new French stamp is a scratch-and-sniff. If you could design a stamp, what would yours feature?
content: A French treasure is being celebrated with its own postage stamp: the baguette. And this one is scratch-and-sniff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Brown
title: The L.A. Roller Rink Where the Years Glide By
description: Moonlight Rollerway has been hosting some of the city’s best skate parties for more than 60 years.
content: On a dark night in February, east of the 5 Freeway, south of the 134, down the street from the so-called Gentlemen’s Club, glows the blue neon sign: Moonlight Rollerway. These are the industrial hinterlands of Glendale, a tidy enclave in the rambling city-state that is Los Angeles, and here, among plumbing supply warehouses and an Amazon delivery van lot, sits a squat cinder-block building, an unexpected portal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Evil’ Review: Is It Satan, or Is It Us? It’s Time to Find Out.
description: Michelle and Robert King’s macabre comedy about the possibility of demonic possession and the certainty of evil begins its final season.
content: Season 3 of “Evil” ended on a typically funny but creepy, outlandish yet somehow understated note. With moments to go in the final episode, Kristen Bouchard, the show’s demon-investigating psychologist, found out that one of her eggs had been fertilized by the sperm of a possible demon. The last thing we saw was her dumbfounded face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: What Trump Looks Like to Historians
description: Trump has changed everything and nothing.
content: When historians and political scientists rank presidents from best to worst, Donald Trump invariably comes out at the bottom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Florida From Criminalizing Transport of Undocumented Immigrants
description: The provision was part of an effort to discourage unauthorized immigrants from living and working in Florida.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked part of a Florida law that criminalized transporting into the state anyone who lacked lawful immigration status, raising new legal questions for other states pursuing similar measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’m a Retired Psychiatrist. Is It OK to Befriend a Former Patient?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on professional boundaries.
content: I am a retired, married, male psychiatrist. A divorced, female former patient of mine contacted me recently, 45 years after her treatment ended. Would it be OK to correspond with her by email? Or is this a case of “once a patient, always a patient?” — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Holocaust Death Toll on English Channel Island Is Raised by Hundreds
description: A panel of academics said it found more conclusive evidence of how many people were killed during the Nazi occupation of Alderney, one of the Channel Islands in British territory.
content: A long-running debate about a small part of Britain’s Holocaust history has been settled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,068, May 22, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and J. David Goodman
title: Uvalde Settles With Victims’ Families Over School Shooting
description: The Texas city agreed to pay $2 million to families of schoolchildren who were shot in a 2022 massacre, and to overhaul its police force. The families are also suing other agencies.
content: The city of Uvalde, Texas, has reached a settlement with most of the families of children who were shot by a gunman at Robb Elementary School in 2022, lawyers for the families said on Wednesday. To avert a lawsuit, the city promised to overhaul the city’s police force, create a permanent memorial to the victims and pay $2 million, the lawyers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Up to this Point
description: Martin Schneider calls ’em like he sees ’em.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: What’s It Like Living Near Elevated Trains? Share Your Photos and Videos.
description: Here’s how to share shots and footage with The New York Times for a story featuring those who live near overhead trains in New York City.
content: Share your photos and videos to contribute to a New York Times story about living near elevated train lines in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Whitney’s Then-and-Now Project Portrays a Changing City
description: The museum has paired its paintings of street scenes with photos of the same spots today.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at paintings from the Whitney Museum of American Art — and what the places in New York that they depict look like today. We’ll also find out about the backlash over CUNY Law School’s decision not to have a student speak at its commencement ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: No Gaza Aid Delivered Through U.S.-Built Pier Has Been Distributed, Pentagon Says
description: The temporary pier is one of few remaining entry points for aid shipments since Israel began an incursion into Rafah, in southern Gaza, earlier this month.
content: None of the food and supplies that have entered the Gaza Strip through a U.S.-built temporary pier in its first five days of operation have been distributed to Palestinians by aid organizations, Gen. Patrick S. Ryder, the Pentagon spokesman, said at a news briefing on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Three European Nations Recognized a Palestinian State
description: Also, another provocative flag was flown at Justice Alito’s home. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Leaders of Spain, Norway and Ireland said today that their governments would recognize an independent Palestinian state, despite vehement Israeli and American opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden Cancels Billions in Student Loan Debt, a Centerpiece of His Campaign
description: The announcement applied to 160,000 borrowers and brings the total debt canceled by the administration to $167 billion.
content: President Biden announced another round of student loan forgiveness on Wednesday, canceling $7.7 billion in debt for 160,000 people in what has become a centerpiece of his campaign for re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Kit Connor and Rachel Zegler Headline Broadway ‘Romeo and Juliet’
description: A production featuring the screen stars, with music by Jack Antonoff, will open in October at Circle in the Square.
content: Rachel Zegler has already played a Juliet-inspired figure, starring as Maria in the 2021 film adaptation of “West Side Story.” And Kit Connor has played a Romeo of sorts, starring as a yearning adolescent in the boy-meets-boy television series “Heartstopper.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What Does It Mean to Recognize a Palestinian State?
description: The move by three European countries fits into a long-term goal of Palestinian leaders to secure diplomatic acceptance, but the immediate impact may be limited.
content: The decision by three European countries — Ireland, Norway and Spain — to recognize a Palestinian state fits into a long-term goal of Palestinian leaders to secure diplomatic acceptance, but it appears that the immediate practical impact will be limited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: America Is Losing the Green Tech Race to China
description: The Biden administration seems to be in denial about China’s staggering advantage.
content: On May 14, President Biden announced a major escalation of the country’s emerging climate trade war with China, raising existing tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles to 100 percent — a unilateral quadrupling. A few days earlier, responding to reports of Biden’s plans, Donald Trump outdid him, promising tariffs of 200 percent should he win the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Hunter Biden’s Trial on Tax Charges Is Pushed to September
description: The judge presiding over the case in Los Angeles agreed to delay the start of his trial to Sept. 5.
content: The judge presiding over Hunter Biden’s tax case in Los Angeles agreed on Wednesday to delay the start of his trial to Sept. 5, giving his lawyers room to prepare for a separate trial on a firearms charge in Delaware early next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
title: House Panel Seeks F.B.I. Investigation Into Doping by Chinese Swimmers
description: The bipartisan request for a criminal inquiry relies on a law that gives the Justice Department the power to prosecute doping offenses that do not occur in the United States.
content: The House select committee on China has asked the Justice Department and F.B.I. to investigate reports that Chinese authorities covered up positive doping tests for nearly half the swim team it sent to the last Olympic Games and that the global antidoping regulator failed to take action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: coalesce
description: This word has appeared in 113 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word coalesce has appeared in 113 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 10 in “Klimt Landscape Show Is More, and Less, Than Expected” by Roberta Smith:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: ‘Where Did Justine Go?’ One Woman Disappears Into Devotion
description: Justine Payton was drawn to a Hare Krishna ashram for its yoga, meditation and vegan meals. She’s still figuring out what went wrong.
content: A few days before Christmas in 2020, quarantined with Covid in the basement of a Hare Krishna ashram in Philadelphia, Justine Payton admitted to herself how bad things had gotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirsten Grind
title: A Running Mate’s History: $1 Billion, Cocaine, a Fling With Elon Musk
description: Nicole Shanahan, a lawyer who was married to Sergey Brin, a Google founder, led a rarefied and sometimes turbulent life in Silicon Valley, according to a Times examination.
content: When Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was considering potential running mates for his presidential run, his shortlist was initially topped by two well-known men with unusual résumés: Aaron Rodgers, the N.F.L. quarterback and frequent purveyor of conspiracy theories, and Jesse Ventura, the former governor of Minnesota and professional wrestler known as “The Body.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: How ‘America’s Monster’ Operated in Afghanistan
description: Plus, three European countries recognize a Palestinian state.
content: General Abdul Raziq was one of America’s fiercest allies in the fight against the Taliban. He was young and charismatic — a courageous warrior who commanded the loyalty and respect of his men. He helped beat back the Taliban in the crucial battlefield of Kandahar, even as the insurgents advanced across Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Tornado Pummels Wind Turbines in Iowa
description: The damage was unusual, experts say, because turbines are built to withstand extreme weather. Iowa is a wind powerhouse, with thousands of turbines.
content: The footage from southwest Iowa is shocking: In the trail of a tornado, a wind turbine is bent in half like a cheap straw, its hub engulfed in flames and thick black smoke, its blades on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: ‘Selling the Hamptons’: Real Estate Drama on Long Island
description: On the reality TV show, a motley crew of camera-ready real estate agents navigates the cutthroat market of multimillion dollar houses.
content: Like the Hamptons itself, where white-sand beaches and white-glove service await those with enough equity each summer, the reality TV show “Selling the Hamptons” is an escape and an indulgence. Now in its second season on Max, the streaming service formerly known as HBO Max, the show follows the cast in the storied vacationland of moneyed New Yorkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: French Leader Heads to Pacific Outpost Gripped by Deadly Unrest
description: It remains unclear what strategy President Emmanuel Macron of France will pursue to defuse tensions in New Caledonia, where six people have died in recent days.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France is making a surprise trip to New Caledonia, a French territory in the South Pacific that has been gripped by deadly unrest for more than a week, to hold talks with pro-independence leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: How Today’s Economy Could Matter in November
description: Some pollsters and economists believe voters form their perceptions of the economy over time.
content: Syd Ortiz thinks we’re heading toward another Great Depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Conniff
title: The End of Polio Is in Sight. What Have We Learned?
description: The lessons learned in this global health success story can be used to fight other deadly diseases.
content: The fight to eradicate polio has been long and difficult. It’s been nearly 50 years since vaccines eliminated the disease in the United States. But polio continues to this day disabling or killing children in some harder to reach parts of the world. The good news is that we are now on the cusp of eradicating this terrible disease everywhere and forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azam Ahmed, Matthieu Aikins and Bryan Denton
title: America’s Monster
description: How the United States backed kidnapping, torture and murder in Afghanistan.
content: The convoy rumbled into the Taliban heartland, a white desert littered with stones. Over the loudspeakers at the local mosque, the Afghan police officers ordered everyone to gather: The commander was here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Why a Prosecutor Went Public With Arrest Warrant Requests for Hamas and Israeli Leaders
description: What to know about Karim Khan’s decision to seek arrest warrants for three Hamas leaders as well as Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and defense minister, Yoav Gallant.
content: The decision of Karim Khan, the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor, to publicly seek arrest warrants for the leaders of Hamas and Israel this week will be one of the most significant and contentious of his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Schumer Plans Vote on Contraception Access, Teeing Up a Campaign Issue
description: Democrats are planning to spotlight Republicans’ opposition to legislation protecting birth control access nationwide, as part of an election-year push.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, plans next month to fast-track a Senate vote on a bill to protect access to contraception nationwide, the start of an election-year push to highlight Republicans’ record of opposing reproductive rights that voters view as at risk of being stripped away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Reva Goldberg, Christina Djossa, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez and Dan Powell
title: Peter Gallagher’s Marriage Advice? Don’t Get Divorced.
description: Having a decades-long marriage in Hollywood is rare, but actor Peter Gallagher has managed to make it 41 years with his wife, Paula Harwood.
content: Actor Peter Gallagher (Sex, Lies, & Videotape and The O.C.) met his wife, Paula Harwood, over forty years ago in college in a stairwell meet-cute. Since then, they’ve maintained a loving marriage and managed to raise a family while navigating the world of show business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Michael Gold
title: A Day of Negative Headlines for Trump Points to a Cure for Voter ‘Amnesia’
description: In roughly 24 hours on Tuesday, former President Donald J. Trump reposted a video with an echo of Nazi Germany, hinted at restricting contraception and made news in two of the criminal cases against him.
content: President Biden has been battling a new phenomenon in American politics: what Democrats and pollsters have taken to calling “Trump amnesia,” a softening of feeling about his predecessor’s tumultuous term as president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jim Tankersley, Shannon M. Lin, Eric Krupke, Carlos Prieto, Rikki Novetsky, Lexie Diao, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Biden’s Open War on Hidden Fees
description: Targeting “junk fees” from the likes of airlines and credit-card companies has been a way for the president to show Americans that he’s acting to lower prices.
content: The Biden administration is trying to crack down on sneaky fees charged by hotels, rental cars, internet providers and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Sparring in Trump Documents Hearing Highlights Case’s Slow Pace
description: A prosecutor got into a heated exchange with Judge Aileen Cannon over a minor point, as the case continues to crawl.
content: The judge handling former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case in Florida got into a heated exchange with a federal prosecutor on Wednesday over a minor but bitterly contested issue, highlighting again how bogged down the proceedings have become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins and Victor J. Blue
title: Who Was Abdul Raziq?
description: Uncovering the brutal career of a crucial American ally — and the hidden truths of the war in Afghanistan.
content: I first heard about Abdul Raziq in early 2009, when I was a young freelance journalist newly arrived in southern Afghanistan. By chance, I had befriended two drug smugglers who told me that a powerful police commander in the area was helping them ship two metric tons of opium to Iran each month. Raziq, I learned, had a fearsome reputation in his hometown, Spin Boldak, on the border with Pakistan. Everyone I spoke to knew about the Taliban suspects tortured and dumped in the desert. Just as they knew that Raziq was a close ally of the U.S. military. My smuggler friends had offered to introduce me to Raziq, and 10 days after my arrival in Spin Boldak, he returned to town for his grandmother’s funeral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: New ‘Richard III’ Raises an Old Question: Who Should Wear the Crown?
description: A production at the Shakespeare’s Globe theater faced criticism because a nondisabled actor plays the scheming king. But disputes like these miss the point, our critic writes.
content: When Michelle Terry, the artistic director at Shakespeare’s Globe theater in London, decided to put on a production of “Richard III” with a feminist twist, she probably didn’t expect accusations of discrimination. But that’s what she got. The run-up to the show’s premiere on Tuesday was overshadowed by a controversy over the fact that Terry had cast herself as the villainous title character despite not having a physical disability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Eric Weinberg, ‘Scrubs’ Producer, Ordered to Stand Trial in Rape Case
description: The writer and producer was charged in October 2022 with sexually assaulting at least five women, prosecutors said.
content: Eric Weinberg, a writer and producer on the television series “Scrubs,” was ordered on Tuesday to stand trial on 28 counts of rape and sexual battery, after he was charged in 2022 with sexually assaulting at least five women, court records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaad D'Souza
title: Sabrina Carpenter and Chappell Roan Saw a Gap in Pop, and Filled It
description: Two pure pop songs, “Espresso” and “Good Luck, Babe!,” may give the aspiring stars behind them a boost from music’s middle class to the big time.
content: The caffeinated drink of the summer isn’t cold brew or iced matcha — it’s “me espresso,” a weird and strangely brilliant neologism coined by the pop singer Sabrina Carpenter in her ascendant hit “Espresso.” The track — sugary sweet, fiendishly catchy and meme-ready — has been out for only a month and change, but it is already one of the defining songs of 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: Under Relentless Russian Assault, Ukraine Adopts a Defensive Crouch
description: As Moscow’s forces retake land from which they were ousted at the end of 2022, the Ukrainian military has adopted a strategy of fighting while slowly falling back to more heavily fortified positions.
content: At a high point for Ukraine in its war against Russia, when its army was sweeping Russian forces from the country’s northeast, a small-town police chief proudly hung a Ukrainian flag on his newly liberated city hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Shirley Conran, Author Best Known for the Steamy ‘Lace,’ Dies at 91
description: A divorced single mother, she started out to write a sex guide for schoolgirls and ended up with a tale of female autonomy that became a best-selling novel.
content: Shirley Conran, the industrious and proliferous British author whose 1982 novel, “Lace,” was a tale of female autonomy disguised as a bonkbuster (to use the British term for a steamy best seller) that made her a millionaire and introduced the lowly goldfish into the erotic canon, died on May 9 in London. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Iran’s Use of Proxy Warfare Likely to Persist, Experts Say
description: The sudden death of President Ebrahim Raisi is not expected to affect the actions of groups like Hezbollah and the Houthis, which are vital to Iran’s power.
content: While uncertainty surrounds political succession in Iran after its president and foreign minister died in a helicopter crash, analysts say it is unlikely their deaths will alter the country’s projection of power through heavily armed allied groups in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Mari
title: What Do Students at Elite Colleges Really Want?
description: Many of Harvard’s Generation Z say “sellout” is not an insult.
content: The meme was an image of a head with “I need to get rich” slapped across it. “Freshmen after spending 0.02 seconds on campus,” read the caption, posted in 2023 to the anonymous messaging app Sidechat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: The Best Crime Novels of the Year (So Far)
description: Looking for some murder and mayhem (fictional, of course)? Here are the best crime novels of 2024 so far.
content: We chose the 10 best crime novels of 2023. See the complete list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Nvidia, Powered by A.I. Boom, Reports Soaring Revenue and Profits
description: The Silicon Valley company was again lifted by sales of its artificial intelligence chips, but it faces growing competition and heightened expectations.
content: Nvidia, which makes microchips that power most artificial intelligence applications, began an extraordinary run a year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Like Your Movies Odd and Grungy? Try Cultpix.
description: This streaming service collects low-budget, high-creativity movies with outsider status. We single out some of the best on offer.
content: Few words in the cinematic sphere are misappropriated as frequently and as flagrantly as “cult” (no, friends, “Mean Girls,” a pop culture phenomenon as well as critical and commercial success upon its initial release, is not a “cult classic”), so one of the many refreshing pleasures of the streaming service Cultpix is that the titles it streams are honest-to-God cult movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Two Wild Movies at Cannes Have Everybody Arguing
description: “The Substance” features Demi Moore in go-for-broke mode, while “Emilia Pérez” is a musical crime drama that defies description.
content: Maybe “Megalopolis” was just an amuse-bouche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Parnell
title: The Words That Defined the Week in Donald J. Trump’s Trial
description: An aggressive cross-examination, a judge’s scolding and then a pause before the jury considers the case.
content: The criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, the first prosecution of an American president, wrapped up its abbreviated sixth week with both the prosecution and defense resting their cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Minutes Show Officials Were Wary About Inflation at May Meeting
description: Federal Reserve policymakers were still willing to raise rates if the economy surprised them, notes from their most recent meeting suggested.
content: Federal Reserve officials were wary about the recent lack of progress on inflation and remained willing to lift interest rates if conditions made it necessary as of their two-day meeting that ended on May 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Ann Hinga Klein and Leah McBride Mensching
title: ‘A Completely Different Town Now’: A Community Reels From a Deadly Tornado
description: Multiple people died in Greenfield, Iowa, population 2,000, where search and rescue efforts were continuing on Wednesday.
content: The tornado had just hit Greenfield, Iowa, and residents were already using skid loaders to clear streets. With the hospital damaged, they took the wounded to a medical triage center at the local lumberyard. And across western Iowa, paramedics and police officers were speeding toward the small town to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Emily Anthes
title: A Second Dairy Worker Has Contracted Bird Flu, C.D.C. Reports
description: The new case, in a Michigan farmworker, did not suggest that bird flu was widespread in people, health officials said, adding that the risk to the general public remained low.
content: A farmworker in Michigan has been diagnosed with bird flu, state officials announced on Wednesday, making it the second human case associated with the outbreak in cows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emile Ducke
title: Evacuation Point
description: As they evacuated from the fighting in Ukraine, the passengers already thought of what they left behind.
content: This little bus was filled with people from Vovchansk and the smaller villages around it, in the path of Russia’s surge into the Kharkiv region of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: U.C.L.A. Removes Police Chief in the Wake of a Protest Melee
description: University of California, Los Angeles, officials have been widely criticized for their failure to stop attacks on pro-Palestinian protesters at a campus demonstration.
content: The campus police chief for the University of California, Los Angeles, has been removed from his post in the aftermath of a violent, hourslong attack on a pro-Palestinian encampment at the school, during which security officers did not intervene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,069, May 23, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Here’s Why Republicans Are Focusing on Voting by Noncitizens
description: House Republicans are pushing legislation to crack down on voting by noncitizens, which is allowed in some local elections but illegal — and exceedingly rare — at the federal level.
content: House Republicans are pushing legislation to crack down on voting by noncitizens, part of an effort to sow doubts about the election outcome and take aim at immigrants who they say have no business participating in elections in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 20, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 20, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 346, May 22, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Testing the Nvidia Boom
description: Expectations are sky-high for the chipmaker’s latest earnings report. The company is at the center of Wall Street’s focus on artificial intelligence.
content: Despite concerns about stubbornly high inflation, elevated interest rates and ballooning U.S. debt, the S&P 500 is trading at a record on Wednesday, having soared 27 percent over the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Passarella
title: First Aid Basics Everyone Should Know
description: This expert advice will help you attend to common injuries like cuts, burns and sprains — and know when to head to the doctor.
content: This expert advice will help you attend to common injuries like cuts, burns and sprains — and know when to head to the doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: What’s in Our Queue? Kacey Musgraves and More
description: I’ve been a reporter at the Paris bureau of The New York Times for nearly a decade. Here are five things that I’ve been enjoying recently.
content: I’ve been a reporter at the Paris bureau of The New York Times for nearly a decade. Here are five things that I’ve been enjoying recently.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Multnomah County, Ore. District Attorney Election Results
description: Get live results from the 2024 Oregon elections.
content: Get live results from the 2024 Oregon elections.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, May 20, 2024
description: New York State’s court system is releasing transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial against former President Donald J. Trump.
content: New York State’s court system is releasing transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Federal Judge’s Ruling
description: A federal judge temporarily blocked part of a Florida law that criminalized transporting into the state anyone who lacked lawful immigration status, raising new legal questions for other states pursuing similar measures.
content: A federal judge temporarily blocked part of a Florida law that criminalized transporting into the state anyone who lacked lawful immigration status, raising new legal questions for other states pursuing similar measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Gabriel Blanco and Claire Hogan
title: Trump Does Not Take the Stand, and the Defense Rests
description: The defense rested its case after Donald J. Trump declined to take the stand at his criminal trial. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
content: The defense rested its case after Donald J. Trump declined to take the stand at his criminal trial. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikolay Nikolov, Azam Ahmed, Bryan Denton, Matthieu Aikins, Ruru Kuo, James Surdam, Dave Horn, Marion Lozano and Daniel Powell
title: How We Tracked Killings on the Ground in Afghanistan
description: Abdul Raziq’s forces disappeared thousands of people to sow fear and cement his power as commander in Kandahar, Afghanistan. He was the Americans’ man — and he may have cost them the war.
content: Abdul Raziq’s forces disappeared thousands of people to sow fear and cement his power as commander in Kandahar, Afghanistan. He was the Americans’ man — and he may have cost them the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Singapore Airlines Passenger Describes Turbulence
description: Turbulence during the London-to-Singapore flight slammed some passengers and crew into the ceiling, leaving dozens of people injured and one dead.
content: Turbulence during the London-to-Singapore flight slammed some passengers and crew into the ceiling, leaving dozens of people injured and one dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press and Storyful
title: Midwest Storms Destroy Homes
description: The storms hit Iowa particularly hard, leaving a mess of debris in Greenfield.
content: The storms hit Iowa particularly hard, leaving a mess of debris in Greenfield.
source.name: The New York Times
